instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
With screen connected 

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is 0v

<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> pin 12 is 0v, pin 10 is 12.56v, pin 17 is 3.34v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Do you get image, only missing backlight???
Check for USB activity at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message: Yeah need to know is this no image, no backlight or no post. USB activity present? External video present? Tried known good screen? Any history liquid drop etc?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Sorry, I was testing this with a bad LCD, with good LCD I get folder no backlight.

Sorry for the tonto question, but is there a screen I can use to test all this boards that use the same connector, say a retina 13" on a retina 15" diferent model year? How about an Air screen on a retina board? I know this is silly to ask but I don't have many parts to test and I am curious about this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
First check on schematic if LCD connectors have the same layout.
Second, and most important, Apple changed LCD firmware like hell; almost every year.
You can find on Internet some screen compatibility; on the forum should find something too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Thanks, will do!

Now no backlight troubleshooting

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is 0v"
Still the same at LCD connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message: You can use 13 vs 15 Retina screens interchangeably for testing; HOWEVER, the 2015 is a different screen than the others. Late 2012/Early 2013, Late 2013/Mid 2014, and 2015 all different screens. MacBook Air screen will definitely not work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
[USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] yes still 0 volts with good LCD on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>

Gracias [USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Post voltage and diode mode at SCL/SDA lines of <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>.
We still pending about history fault.
Also post diode mode to ground at both pins of <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message: L7720 was done, replaced it and realized [LEFT][COLOR=#111111][FONT=inherit]<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground and the LCD connector was damaged, begginer mistake, that should have been the first thing I had to check, replaced that and the LCD cable as well and al is done and fix, thanks a lot gentleman.[/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]
